char.desc: „Einweisungzeichen“ mit einem nach rechts weisendem Querbalken.
„Einweisungzeichen“ mit zwei nach rechts weisendem Querbalken.
Griechisches Kreuz (gleichschenklig und auf einer Spitze stehend).
Das Zeichen ähnelt einer öffnenden eckigen Klammer und markiert den Beginn eines neuen textuellen Abschnitts, wo vorher kein solcher Abschnitt begann

In 18th century there were different ways to represent parentheses in handwritten documents. Then the token most often used (default symbol) was a vertical stroke combined with a colon. We want to be able to differentiate between this default representation, which we encode as normal parenthesis characters, and the very (same) characters, that are used today, and that also appear in documents of that time. Therefore we encode the contemporary representation of parantheses, if encountered in handwritten documents, as glyphs.
See the description of LEFT PARANTHESIS.
The suspension/truncation sign, in German known as “Abbrechungszeichen”.

sp.speaker: Mephisto
sp.p: Absatz: Nun ſind wir ſchon wieder an der Gränze unſres Witzes, da wo euch Menſchen der Sinn überſchnappt. Warum machſt du Gemeinſchaft mit uns, wenn du ſie nicht durchführen kannſt? Willſt fliegen und biſt vorm Schwindel nicht ſicher? Drangen wir uns dir auf, oder du dich uns?

p.del: We never spoke of this to each other;

div.p:
All this - Vanessas But we never spoke, during those unhappy years, of this what was made them, to this "being in love". of these scenes; Thoby, I imagine, may have had some vague conception that something, as I think he would have put it, was up between Jack & Vanessa. But his general attitude was rather aloof, & judicial. conventional: that is, he From his remote station, as a schoolboy, as an undergraduate, he saw felt us in the traditional position:
generaly generally
allied by the old ties: sisters who we
should accept our place: if George wanted us to go to parties, why not? If father wanted us to walk with him, why not? Once, at Salisbury, when the Fishers were our neighbours, & Vanessa, detesting Aunt Mary, who had most viciously intervened, with writing surreptitious letters addressed to Copes School, in the chronic warfare between Vanessa & Jack, Vanessa & George, refused to visit , & cut the them & cut them in the street, he made one of his rare impressive cont statements: it was Gruffly he said he said it was not right to treat Aunt Mary like that. How little he knew.

It thus came about that Nessa & I formed together a v a very close, conspiracy.During those years theIn that large house, the parties Even if we were silent about her affair with Jack, it was that was the only reserve we had. In that world of many men, we were the two coming & going, we formed the our private nucleus. There we were alone, with father all day; in the evening, Adrian would come back from Westminster; then Jack from Lincolns Inn; then Gerald from Dents or Henrietta House; then George from the Post office or the Treasury. & in the holidays Thoby would Thoby would be at Clifton or at Cambridge.The staple day would be a day spent together. And therefore we made together a small world inside the big world. We had an alliance that was so knit together that everything w (with the exception of Jack perhaps) was seen from the same angle; by o & took its shape from our own vantage points. Very soon after Stella's death we had saw life as a perpetual struggle to make our get some kind of standing place for ourselves in this bewildering, bafflingb. always changing, almost always per d We were always battling for that which was always being interfered with, snuffled up, snatched away. The most imminent obstacle & pr burden was of course father. How could we, to take a concrete case, arrange that he should be out when perhaps Kitty Maxse, perhaps Katie Thynne came to tea? How could we escape Mr Bryce? Must I spend the afternoon walking round Kensington Garden? Could we possibly arrange to take our friends straight up to the Studio (the day nursery) without Then, what how could what could we talk about at luncheon? Could we avoid Brighton at Easter? Must we be in because Aunt Mary was coming? Over the whole week of these scenes & perpetuals brooded the horror of Wednesday. On that day the weekly books were shown him. If they were over eleven pounds, that lunch was a torture. I waited outside the drawing room door.The books were presented Silence. He was putting on his glasses.A roar. He had read the figures.Then,"You are ruining me... we are shooting Niagara..." But a roar of s He beat his breast. Dropped his pen; & indulged in one of these extraordinary exhibitions of self pity of self dramatisation. He was ruined. He was dyin.. He was He was wrecked to the bone... Silence & Vanessa par. "And you stand there like a block of stone...". He wd would shake all ove.. So to a wild cry that he was deserted, that he was alone ... that we had no sympathy for him. That was of rage against her; of denunciation of her; which made my blood boil with rage: my fingers tremble. Then another attitude. The cheque was signed with a deep groan.. He would shake & quiver, representing (he was curiously dramatic) an old man ruined & an old man cruelly tortured... That over, he would sigh; subside; & say, to me, for whom he had some pity, & He wd would sink his head on his breast. As if he had signed away his own life, he would hand his the cheque to Vanessa. we sat in complete silence. Then subside.. looking generous, worn, excruciated. And then with a profound groan look up, at me, at last & say plaintively, yet with some regret remorse. Then I wd would have my turn for whom he had some pity, I so like him in excitability & say "Well Giny, what about a wa are you doing the afternoon? What about a walk?
I cannot understand the savage brutality.

Down came his fist on the account book. There was a roar. His vein filled. His face flushed. Then he shouted "I am ruined" – Then he This words were only Then he beat his breast.. He went through an extraordinary dramatisation of self pity anger & despair. He was ruined – dying... wantonly tortured by the wanton extravagance of Vanessa & Sophie.. Vanessa stood be by his side dumb. "And you stand there like a block of stone. Dont you pity me? Havent you a word to say to me?" & so on. Vanessa stood by his side absolutely dumb. He thr flung at her all the phrases of frenzy & sarcasm – about shooting Niagara & so on – that came handy. Still she remained static. Then Another attitude was adopted. With a deep groan he picked up his pen & with ostentatiously trembling fingers wrote out the cheque. This was wearily tossed to Vanessa. Slowly & with many groans the pen the account book were put away. Then he sank into his chair & sat with his head on his breast. And then at last, after glancing at a book for a, mo he woud would look up & say half plaintively. "And what are you doing this afternoon, Jinny?"
I was by t trembling now with fury. Never have I felt such rage, a & such frustration. For not a word of my feeling could be expressed.And there once more was his

This, as far as I can describe it, is an unegg unexaggerated account of a bad Wednesday. Even now I can find nothing to say of his behaviour save that it was brutal. If, instead of words, he had used a whip it would have been no more a brutal the brutality of that attack would have been no greater. How can one explain it? It was complex. He had been indulged of course ever since he broke the flower pot & threw the fragments at his mother (whatever the truth of that story) it ran something like that) then Health Delicacy excused that. Then the

Then, as he grew older, there was the genius legend to which wh- I have already referred. Men of genius are gely generally ill to live with.. But there are certain qualifications to be noted – These scenes were never indulged in before men. Fred Maitland for example abso resolutely refused to believe in them when Caroline Emilia (the Quaker Sister) gently tried to insinuate that Leslie sometimes had a temper. If Thoby had presented these books or George being the most typical of Victorians Vctns the explosion would wd have been suppressed. It was then the woman who excited these rages. Was it then the woman who excited these rages? I Why w had he no shame in front of women? Because, I suggest, he the woman was to him a Partly of course because the woman was his slave; but. But that does not explain the self dramatisation: the attitudinising; the histrionic element; the breast beating; the groaning which wh. played so large a part so disgusting a part in these thes
scenes. scn . To explain that, it is is it & its & the it is one must guess that the woman had His absolute dependence upon women perhaps explains that. He needed always a woman to sympathise to flatter. to console. Why And why? Because he was conscious of some his own failure, as a philosopher, as a writer?: Thus & this failure If you It was But
His his creed however, that by which I mean r made him ashamed to confess this need of sympathy to men. the attitude that his intellect made him, ad
adopt with men, forbad made him the most modest, the most reasonable of men. Thus to Fred Maitland & to Herbert Fisher he was almost entirely without vanity without conceit. All Thus And But The attitude public attitude
Then I think Vanessa, on Wednesdays, was the recipient of many suppressions all much discontent, that he had suppressed ; & t her refusal to accept her role, part slave, part angel of sympathy, exacerbated him so that he was probably unconcious of his own barbarous violence. And
would wd have been horrified had anyone said to h of
